revision.text:
{{outdated|talk=Post-2004 update|date=November 2017}} '''20 ans, barakat!''' (20 years is enough!) is a movement in [[France]] and [[Algeria]] founded in 2003 to overturn the [[Algerian Family Code]] in force since June 1984.
They consider this code to contradict the legal equality between women and men proclaimed in Article 29 of the [[Constitution of Algeria|Algerian constitution]], institutionalizing what they call second-class citizenship for women and leading to discrimination and injustices against them.
Among the injustices and discrimination against women in the Algerian law the movement points to the following points: * Polygamy is allowed. * Only divorced women have parental authority over their children. * Women's right to divorce is conditional, while men retain the power to divorce even against the will of the woman. * Having a [[Wali (Islamic legal guardian)|wali]] (matrimonial guardian) has been made optional, but has not been abolished. * Negotiated conditions in the marriage contract are only available to the most educated and informed of women.
In response, the movement demands that the following changes be made to the Family Code: * Prohibition of polygamy. * End of the use of wali (matrimonial guardian). * Introduction of joint parental authority. * Introduction of equal rights to divorce.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.weldd.org/our-voices/algeria-statement-collectif-20-ans-barakat-20-years-enough|title=Algeria: Statement from the Collectif 20 ans barakat (20 Years is Enough!)|accessdate=22 November 2016|website=weldd.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107022122/http://www.weldd.org/our-voices/algeria-statement-collectif-20-ans-barakat-20-years-enough|archivedate=7 November 2017|df=}}</ref>
It includes the following organizations: * In [[Algeria]]: Tharwa Fadhma n’Soumeur, Association SOS Femmes en Détresse, Association Volonté Initiative et Engagement, Association Défense et Promotion des Droits des Femmes, Associatiation Indépendante pour le Triomphe des Droits des Femmes. * In [[France]]: Association 20 ans Barakat, New Ways, Un livre une vie, Coordination 8 Mars.
[[Ourida Chouaki]] was one of the coordinators of the campaign.<ref name=barakat>{{cite book|last1=Sadiqi|first1=Fatima|last2=Ennaji|first2=Moha|title=Women in the Middle East and North Africa: Agents of Change|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781136970375|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=qwiGABIDfIwC|language=en}}</ref>
==External links== * [http://20ansbarakat.free.fr/ 20 ans barakat's website] * [http://www.mediterraneas.org/article.php3?id_article=19 Collectif 20 ans barakat]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Politics of Algeria]]
{{Algeria-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox award | name = Arthur Ross Book Award | current_awards = | image = Arthur Ross Book Award logo.gif | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | description = [[Literary award|Literature]] ([[politics]]-related) | presenter = {{•}}[[Arthur Ross (philanthropist)|Arthur Ross]] (endowment in 2001)
{{•}}[[Council on Foreign Relations]] (administration) | location = | country = United States | reward = Varies | year = 2002 | year2 = | website = [http://www.cfr.org/arba cfr.org/arba] }} The '''Arthur Ross Book Award''' is a [[politics]]-related [[literary award]]. ==History and administration== It was endowed in 2001 by [[Arthur Ross (philanthropist)|Arthur Ross]], an American [[businessman]] and [[philanthropist]],[[Douglas Martin (journalist)|Martin, Douglas]] (September 11, 2007). [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/11/nyregion/11ross.html?_r=1&oref=slogin "Arthur Ross, Investor and Philanthropist Who Left Mark on the Park, Dies at 96"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. Retrieved February 23, 2012. for the purpose of recognizing books that make an outstanding contribution to the understanding of [[foreign policy]] or [[international relations]]. The prize is for nonfiction works from the past two years, in English or translation, and is accompanied by a monetary award. The amount of the prize has varied from year to year but has sometimes consisted of a $30,000 "Gold Medal", a $15,000 "Silver Medal" and a $7,500 "Honorable Mention". The award is administered by the [[Council on Foreign Relations]], an American [[nonprofit]] [[nonpartisan]] membership organization, publisher and [[think tank]] specializing in U.S. foreign policy and international affairs. ==List of winners== ===2000s=== ; 2002 *Gold Medal – [[Robert Skidelsky]] for ''John Maynard Keynes: Fighting for Freedom 1937–1946'' *Silver Medal – [[Lawrence Freedman]] for ''Kennedy's Wars: Berlin, Cuba, Laos, and Vietnam'' *Honorable Mention – [[Walter Russell Mead]] and [[Richard C. Leone]] for ''Special Providence: American Foreign Policy and How It Changed the World'' ; 2003 *Gold Medal – [[Samantha Power]] for ''[[A Problem from Hell: America and the Age of Genocide]]'' *Silver Medal – [[Margaret MacMillan]] for ''[[Paris 1919: Six Months That Changed the World]]'' *Honorable Mention – [[Philip Bobbitt]] for ''[[The Shield of Achilles: War, Peace, and the Course of History]]'' ;2004 *Gold Medal – [[Daniel Benjamin]] and [[Steven Simon]] for ''The Age of Sacred Terror: Radical Islam's War Against America'' *Silver Medal – [[Robert Cooper (strategist)|Robert Cooper]] for ''The Breaking of Nations: Order and Chaos in the Twenty-First Century'' *Honorable Mention – [[Ivo H. Daalder]] and [[James M. Lindsay]] for ''America Unbound: The Bush Revolution in Foreign Policy'' ;2005 *Gold Medal – [[Steve Coll]] for ''[[Ghost Wars: The Secret History of the CIA, Afghanistan, and Bin Laden, from the Soviet Invasion to September 10, 2001]]'' *Silver Medal – [[Stephen Biddle]] for ''Military Power: Explaining Victory and Defeat in Modern Battle'' *Honorable Mention – [[James Mann (writer)|James Mann]] for ''Rise of the Vulcans: The History of Bush's War Cabinet'' ;2006 *Gold Medal – [[Tony Judt]] for ''[[Postwar: A History of Europe Since 1945]]'' *Silver Medal – [[Olivier Roy (professor)|Olivier Roy]] for ''Globalized Islam: The Search for a New Ummah'' *Honorable Mention – [[George Packer]] for ''[[The Assassins' Gate: America in Iraq]]'' ;2007 *Gold Medal – [[Kwame Anthony Appiah]] for ''Cosmopolitanism: Ethics in a World of Strangers'' *Silver Medal – [[Robert L. Beisner]] for ''Dean Acheson: A Life in the Cold War'' *Honorable Mention – [[Thomas E. Ricks (journalist)|Thomas E. Ricks]] for ''[[Fiasco (book)|Fiasco: The American Military Adventure in Iraq, 2003 to 2005]]'' ;2008 *Gold Medal – [[Paul Collier]] for ''[[The Bottom Billion|The Bottom Billion: Why the Poorest Countries Are Failing and What Can Be Done About It]]'' *Silver Medal – [[Trita Parsi]] for ''Treacherous Alliance: The Secret Dealings of Israel, Iran, and the United States'' *Honorable Mention – [[Robert Dallek]] for ''Nixon and Kissinger: Partners in Power'' ;2009 *Gold Medal – [[Philip P. Pan]] for ''Out of Mao's Shadow: The Struggle for the Soul of a New China'' *Silver Medal – [[Ahmed Rashid]] for ''Descent into Chaos: The United States and the Failure of Nation Building in Pakistan, Afghanistan, and Central Asia'' *Honorable Mention – [[Gareth Evans (politician)|Gareth Evans]] for ''The Responsibility To Protect: Ending Mass Atrocity Crimes Once and for All'' ===2010s=== ;2010 *Gold Medal – [[Liaquat Ahamed]] for ''[[Lords of Finance: The Bankers Who Broke the World]]'' *Silver Medal – [[Seth Jones (political scientist)|Seth Jones]] for ''In the Graveyard of Empires: America's War in Afghanistan'' *Honorable Mention – [[Gérard Prunier]] for ''Africa's World War: Congo, the Rwandan Genocide, and the Making of a Continental Catastrophe'' ;2011 *Gold Medal – [[Carmen M. Reinhart]] and [[Kenneth Rogoff]] for ''This Time is Different: Eight Centuries of Financial Folly'' *Silver Medal – [[Thomas Hegghammer]] for ''Jihad in Saudi Arabia: Violence and Pan-Islamism since 1979'' *Honorable Mention – [[Charles A. Kupchan]] for ''How Enemies Become Friends: The Sources of Stable Peace'' ;2012 *Gold Medal – [[John Lewis Gaddis]] for ''[[George F. Kennan: An American Life]]'' *Silver Medal – [[Jason Stearns]] for ''Dancing in the Glory of Monsters: The Collapse of Congo and the Great War of Africa'' *Honorable Mention – [[Daniel Yergin]] for ''[[The Quest: Energy, Security, and the Remaking of the Modern World]]'' ;2013{{cite web |url=http://www.cfr.org/vietnam/fredrik-logevall-wins-cfrs-2013-arthur-ross-book-award-embers-war/p32084 |title=Fredrik Logevall Wins CFR's 2013 Arthur Ross Book Award for "Embers of War" |publisher=Council on Foreign Relations |author= |date=December 16, 2013 |accessdate=August 29, 2014}} *Gold Medal - [[Fredrik Logevall]] for ''[[Embers of War|Embers of War: The Fall of an Empire and the Making of America's Vietnam]]'' *Silver Medal - [[Anne Applebaum]] for ''Iron Curtain: The Crushing of Eastern Europe, 1944–1956 '' *Honorable Mention - [[Daron Acemoglu]] and James A. Robinson for ''[[Why Nations Fail|Why Nations Fail: The Origins of Power, Prosperity, and Poverty]]'' ;2014{{cite web |url=http://www.cfr.org/bangladesh/blood-telegram-gary-bass-wins-cfrs-2014-arthur-ross-book-award/p33869 |title=The Blood Telegram by Gary Bass Wins CFR’s 2014 Arthur Ross Book Award |publisher=Council on Foreign Relations |author= |date=November 25, 2014 |accessdate=March 29, 2015}} *Gold Medal - Gary Bass for ''[[The Blood Telegram: Nixon, Kissinger, and a Forgotten Genocide]]'' *Silver Medal - Carter Malkasian for ''War Comes to Garmser: Thirty Years of Conflict on the Afghan Frontier'' *Honorable Mention - [[Benn Steil]] for ''[[The Battle of Bretton Woods|The Battle of Bretton Woods: John Maynard Keynes, Harry Dexter White, and the Making of a New World Order]]'' ;2015 *Gold Medal – [[Thomas Piketty]] for ''[[Capital in the Twenty-First Century]]'' *Silver Medal – [[Stephen Kotkin]] for ''Stalin: Volume I: Paradoxes of Power, 1878–1928'' *Honorable Mention – [[Evan Osnos]] for ''Age of Ambition: Chasing Fortune, Truth, and Faith in the New China'' ;2016 *Gold Medal – [[Niall Ferguson]] for ''Kissinger: 1923–1968: The Idealist'' *Silver Medal – [[Thomas J. Christensen]] for ''The China Challenge: Shaping the Choices of a Rising Power '' *Bronze Medal – [[Charles Moore (journalist)|Charles Moore]] for ''Margaret Thatcher: The Authorized Biography—Volume II: Everything She Wants'' ;2017{{cite web |url=https://www.cfr.org/news-releases/john-pomfrets-beautiful-country-and-middle-kingdom-wins-2017-cfr-arthur-ross-book-0 |title=John Pomfret’s “The Beautiful Country and the Middle Kingdom” Wins 2017 CFR Arthur Ross Book Award |publisher=Council on Foreign Relations |author= |date=November 15, 2017 |accessdate=December 23, 2017}} *Gold Medal – [[John Pomfret (journalist)|John Pomfret]] for ''The Beautiful Country and the Middle Kingdom: America and China, 1776 to the Present'' *Silver Medal – [[Robert F. Worth]] for ''A Rage for Order: The Middle East in Turmoil, From Tahrir Square to ISIS'' *Bronze Medal – [[Svetlana Alexievich]] for ''Secondhand Time: The Last of the Soviets'' ==See also== {{portal|Books|Literature|Politics}} * [[List of literary awards]] {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|www.cfr.org/arba}} [[Category:2001 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:American literary awards]] [[Category:Annual events in the United States]] [[Category:Awards established in 2001]] [[Category:Books about international relations|*]] [[Category:Foreign policy]] [[Category:Non-fiction literary awards]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2001]] [[Category:Political book awards]] [[Category:Council on Foreign Relations]]

page.title: Association of Peasant Workers of the Carare

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Association of Peasant Workers of the Carare | native_name = Asociación de Trabajadores Campesinos del Carare | native_name_lang = Spanish | named_after = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = | motto = | formation = {{start date and age|1987|06|}} | founder = | founding_location = La India, [[Cimitarra]], Colombia | extinction = <!-- use {{end date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | status = Active | purpose = | headquarters = | location = | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline, title}} --> | region = | services = | products = | methods = | sec_gen = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | slogan = | mission = | website = {{URL|atccvidaypaz.org}} | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} The '''Association of Peasant Workers of the Carare''' (Spanish: ''Asociación de Trabajadores Campesinos del Carare'' (ATCC)) is an organization that was founded in 1987 in the village of La India, part of the municipality of [[Cimitarra]] in north-east Colombia, as a reaction to the ongoing violence between various armed groups in the region. Despite the murder of several of its leaders, it has continued to fight for peace, and in 1990 it was awarded the [[Right Livelihood Award]] in recognition of its work.
== History == Following decades of fighting in the region between guerrilla groups and the Colombian army, later joined in the 1980s by paramilitary fighters, the community of La India had reached breaking point by 1987. A group of peasants asked for a meeting with the guerrillas which took place on May 21, 1987, and asked to be left in peace. The guerrillas accepted the request of the group, and a meeting the following week with the commander of the military forces achieved the same result.<ref name="Semana19910107">{{cite magazine |title=El premio de la paz |url=http://www.semana.com/nacion/articulo/el-premio-de-la-paz/14431-3 |magazine=[[Semana (magazine)|Semana]] |language=Spanish |date=January 7, 1991 |accessdate=August 28, 2017}}</ref> Following the meetings the ATCC was formed. Its aim was to promote economic growth and peace in the region by holding talks with all parties involved in the conflict, while avoiding taking sides. The ATCC obtained a government grant for six million pesos to build a community store and two purchase two canoes to provide transport to the area along the [[Carare River]]. The organization also developed a six-year plan, cosing almost three thousand million pesos, to develop the region.<ref name="Semana19910107" /> The ATCC's plan covers six municipalities in the region and has five goals: to create a program of building a culture of peace and symbolic reparation; a health care and community rehabilitation plan; an agroforestry program to restore the environment and work for the community; a program of organizational strengthening and institutional recovery; and the restoration of collective property. The plan was finally approved on December 15, 2012.<ref name="Espectador20130612">{{cite news |first=Santiago |last=Martínez Hernández |title=Reparación a la lucha sin armas |url=http://www.elespectador.com/noticias/judicial/reparacion-lucha-sin-armas-articulo-427476 |newspaper=[[El Espectador]] |language=Spanish |date=June 12, 2013 |accessdate=August 28, 2017}}</ref>
The ATCC's greatest setback was the murder on February 26, 1990 of its co-founder and president Josué Vargas, its secretary Saúl Castañeda, and its technical advisor Miguel Ángel Barajas, along with London-based [[BBC]] journalist Silvia Duzán who had been interviewing them in a restaurant in Cimitarra.<ref name="Espectador20130612" /><ref name="Tiempo19901021">{{cite news |first=Arturo |last=Jaimes |title=Un Nobel hecho entre fusiles |url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-1287 |newspaper=[[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]] |language=Spanish |date=October 21, 1990 |accessdate=August 28, 2017}}</ref> However, on October 8 of the same year the organization was awarded the [[Right Livelihood Award]] (popularly known as the "Alternative Nobel Prize") in recognition of its work in standing up to the violence.<ref name="Semana19910107" /><ref name="Tiempo19901021" />
During the 1990s the ATCC was involved in a struggle to convince local farmers not to accede to the demands of guerrilla groups and plant coca.<ref>{{cite book |first=Oliver |last=Kaplan |title=Resisting War: How Communities Protect Themselves |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |page=191 |date=2017 |isbn=978-1-10715-980-8}}</ref> Between 2001 and 2004 the organization also had to stand up to further outbreaks of violence that took place in the area.<ref name="Espectador20130612" />
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Anti-war activists]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1987]] [[Category:Peace organizations]] [[Category:Right Livelihood Award laureates]]

{{Infobox organization | name = '''Czech Geological Society''' | bgcolor = <!-- header background color --> | fgcolor = <!-- header text color --> | image = | image_border = | size = <!-- default 200px --> | alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> | caption = | map = <!-- optional --> | msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | malt = <!-- map alt text --> | mcaption = <!-- optional --> | map2 = | abbreviation = CGS | motto = | predecessor = | successor = | formation = 1923 | extinction = <!-- date of extinction, optional --> | type = [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] | status = | purpose = Promotion of education, scientific research and publication | headquarters = | location = | coords = | region_served = [[Czech Republic]] | membership = | language = <!-- official languages --> | general = Martin Ivanov | leader_title = President | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = Annual General Meeting and Elected Council | parent_organization = <!-- if one --> | affiliations = | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = http://www.geologickaspolecnost.cz | remarks = | former name = Czechoslovak Society for Mineralogy and Geology }} '''Czech Geological Society''' is a non-profit organization dedicated to the advancement of the geosciences. It provides access to elements that are essential to the professional growth of earth scientists at all levels of expertise and from all sectors: academic, government, business, and industry. CGS is a member of the Czech Council of Scientific Societies<ref name=RVS>[http://rvs.avcr.cz/o-rvs/clenske-spolecnosti/ Czech Council of Scientific Societies]</ref> and the [[Association of European Geological Societies]] (AEGS). Through the Czech National Geological Committee,<ref name=CNGK>[http://www.geology.cz/cngk/ CNGK]</ref> CGS is also linked to the [[International Union of Geological Sciences]]. CGS takes an active role in various programs of international professional associations, such as [[IAGOD]] and [[International Geoscience Programme|IGCP]].<ref name=home>[http://www.geologickaspolecnost.cz/Czech-Geological-Society/ CGS homepage]</ref>
==History== The Society was founded in 1923 as a Czechoslovak Society for Mineralogy and Geology.
==Membership== The society has about 530 members.<ref name=rvsReport>[http://rvs.paleontologie.cz/spolecnosti/spol-6/ Yearly reports for the Czech Council of Scientific Societies]</ref>
===Activities=== The Society's primary activities are organizing scientific meetings and lecture series, publishing scientific literature and organizing field excursions open to general public.
==Publications== The Society publishes [[Journal of Geosciences]] (formerly Časopis pro mineralogii a geologii and Journal of the Czech Geological Society), a quarterly peer-review scientific journal.<ref name=jgeosci>[http://www.jgeosci.org/ Jgeosci homepage]</ref> Twice a year, all members of the Society receive a Bulletin with up-to-date information on seminars, exhibitions, excursions and mineral shows to take place both in the country and elsewhere in Central Europe, new books and films, and a social chronicle.
==Conferences== * 1997 - MAEGS-10: 10th Meeting of the Association of European Geological Societies * 1997 - Tourmaline (1997) * 1998 - Granite Pegmatites - Mineralogy, Petrology & Geochemistry * 2005 - Slavonice 2005: 2nd Meeting of the CGS * 2007 - Volary 2007: 3rd Meeting of the CGS * 2009 - Joint meeting of SGS and CGS Bratislava 2009 * 2011 - Joint meeting of SGS and CGS Monínec 2011
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Geology societies]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Science and technology in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:1923 establishments in Czechoslovakia]] [[Category:Scientific organizations established in 1923]]

revision.text:
[[File:Daylight saving time in Asia.svg|thumb|right|350px| {{legend|#1a80e6|Currently using [[daylight saving time|DST]]}} {{legend|#ee690a|Formerly used [[daylight saving time|DST]] (West Malaysia, Singapore and Turkey uses year-round DST)}} {{legend|#ff0000|Never used [[daylight saving time|DST]]}}]]
As of 2017, '''[[daylight saving time]]''' is used in the following Asian countries:
* {{flag|Cyprus}}: From last Sunday March to last Sunday October; follows [[European Union]] practice. The [[Turkish Republic of North Cyprus]] uses year-round summer time with no change in winter. * {{flag|Iran}}: From March 21–22 to September 21–22 (1 Farvardin to 30 Shahrivar); Starts on the second or third day of [[Nowruz]] * {{flag|Israel}}: From Friday before the last Sunday of March to last Sunday October * {{flag|Jordan}}: From last Friday March to last Friday October * {{flag|Lebanon}}: From last Sunday March to last Sunday October * {{flagicon|Palestine}} [[Palestinian territories]]: From last Saturday March to last Saturday October * {{flag|Syria}}: From last Friday March to last Friday October * {{flag|Turkey}}: Currently year-round with no change in the winter. This includes the [[Turkish Republic of North Cyprus]].
==By country==
==={{flagu|China, People's Republic of}}=== {{Main|Time in China}}
The [[China|People's Republic of China]] experimented with DST from 1986, but abandoned DST from 1992 onwards. The PRC now uses one time zone (UTC+8) for the whole country.
=== {{flagu|Egypt}} === {{Main|Egypt Standard Time|Daylight saving time in Egypt}}
The British first instituted [[summer time]] in Egypt in 1940, during the [[Second World War]]. The practice was stopped after 1945, but resumed 12 years later, in 1957.<ref name="wapo2016" />
Before the [[Egyptian revolution of 2011|revolution in January 2011]], the government was planning to take a decision to abolish summer time in 2011 before President [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s term expires in September 2011. The [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|transitional government]] did so on 20 April 2011.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/407168 |title=Egypt to cancel daylight saving time}}</ref>
Under the pretext that daylight saving time would save energy, the Egyptian government decided on 7 May 2014 to reinstate summer time with an exception for the holy month of [[Ramadan]].<ref name=dst2>{{Cite web |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/101285.aspx |title=Daylight saving to be applied in Egypt starting Friday}}</ref> In April the next year, a poll was held on whether to apply summer time or not. Following the results, the government decided on 20 April to temporarily cancel summer time, to make the necessary amendment to the laws and asked the ministers to work on a study to determine the probability of applying DST in coming years or not.<ref name=dst1>{{Cite web |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/128195/Egypt/Politics-/No-daylight-saving-this-summer-Egypts-prime-minist.aspx |title=No daylight saving this summer: Egypt's prime minister}}</ref> The ministry of electricity assured that the achieved electricity savings from applying summer time is not of any tangible effect.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.egynews.net/%D9%85%D8%AC%D9%84%D8%B3-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%88%D8%B2%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%A1-%D9%8A%D8%B1%D8%AC%D8%A6-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B9%D9%85%D9%84-%D8%A8%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AA%D9%88%D9%82%D9%8A%D8%AA-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B5%D9%8A/ |title=Council of Ministers Postpones Using Summer Time This Year}} {{link language|ar}}</ref> Summer time was expected to return in 2016, starting on July 8 (after [[Ramadan]]), but on July 5, it was decided to again cancel it.<ref name="wapo2016">{{Cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2016/07/06/egypt-cancelled-daylight-savings-time-three-days-before-it-was-due-to-start/ |title=Egypt canceled daylight saving time three days before it was due to start |first=Adam |last=Taylor |date=July 6, 2016 |work=[[The Washington Post]]}}</ref>
==={{flagu|Hong Kong}}=== Hong Kong used DST beginning in 1941, but abandoned it from 1980 onwards.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.weather.gov.hk/gts/time/Summertime.htm |title=Hong Kong Observatory: Hong Kong Summer Time |publisher=[[Hong Kong Observatory]] |date=2009-10-02 |accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref>
==={{flagu|India}}=== British India used [[Daylight Saving Time]] (DST) briefly during wartime in 1942–1945 while under british rule. Currently, India does not observe DST.
==={{flagu|Iran}}=== [[Iran]] observed DST in 1977–1980, 1991–2005 and since 2008 from March 21–22 (1/1 [[Iranian calendars]]) to September 21–22 (6/30 Iranian calendars).
==={{flagu|Israel}}=== {{Main|Israel Summer Time}} [[Israel]] observed DST in 1940–1946, 1948–1957, 1974–1975 and since 1985. Currently, DST is observed from the Friday before the last Sunday of March to the last Sunday of October.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.jpost.com/Diplomacy-and-Politics/Knesset-votes-to-extend-Daylight-Saving-Time-319157 |title=Knesset votes to extend Daylight Saving Time |work=jpost.com |date=8 July 2013 |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref>
==={{flagu|Jordan}}=== [[Jordan]] UTC+3 observed daylight saving time from the last Friday of March to the last Friday of October. On October 24, 2012, Jordan decided to continue observing daylight saving time for an entire year, ending in December 2013.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://m.alrai.com/article/547501.html |script-title=ar:الغاء التوقيت الشتوي |accessdate=2012-10-24 |last= |first= |authorlink= |author=Faris Abawi |date=24 October 2012 |work=Al Rai newspaper |pages=1 |language=ar |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121027012133/http://m.alrai.com/article/547501.html |archivedate=2012-10-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.worldtimezone.com/dst_news/dst_news_jordan03.html |title=Jordan cancels decision to switch to wintertime |accessdate=2012-10-24 |author= |last= |first= |authorlink= |vauthors= |date=24 October 2012 |work= |publisher=WorldTimeZone.com |pages=1 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130127090034/http://www.worldtimezone.com/dst_news/dst_news_jordan03.html |archivedate=2013-01-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==={{flagu|Kazakhstan}}===
[[Kazakhstan]] made a decision to stop observing summer time in 2005, citing health complications as well as lowered productivity and a lack of economic benefits.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.kazsociety.org.uk/news/2005/03/30.htm |title=Kazakhstan abolishes daylight saving time |date=2005-03-21 |accessdate=2007-03-28 |publisher=Kazakhstan Society in the UK |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070106201952/http://www.kazsociety.org.uk/news/2005/03/30.htm |archivedate=2007-01-06 |df= }}</ref>
==={{flagu|Kyrgyzstan}}=== [[Kyrgyzstan]] voted to stop observing DST in 2005 and make UTC+6 as Standard Time (which used to be Kyrgyzstan Summer Time), thus having permanent DST due to the timezone shift.
==={{flagu|Malaysia}}=== Malaysia used DST from January 1, 1933, but discontinued on December 31, 1981 to replace DST with [[Malaysian Standard Time]].
==={{flagu|South Korea}}=== [[South Korea]] observed DST from 1948–51, from 1955–60, and from 1987–88. South Korea does not currently observe DST.
==={{flagu|Syria}}=== [[Syria]] observed DST at UTC+3, in 2006 from 30 March until 21 September (a change from 30 September). Now, DST is observed from the last Friday of March to the last Friday of October.
==={{flagu|Taiwan}}=== [[Taiwan]] implemented DST from 1945–61, revoked DST from 1962–73, reinstated DST from 1974–75, revoked DST from 1976–79 and reinstated it in 1980. Taiwan abandoned DST from 1981 onwards.
==={{flagu|Turkey}}=== [[Turkey]] is currently observing year-round daylight saving from September 2016. DST was used from 1985–2016.
==Asian countries not using DST== These countries or regions do not use daylight saving time, although some have in the past: # {{flag|Afghanistan}} # {{flag|Armenia}} (Observed DST in 1981–1995, 1997–2011) # {{flag|Azerbaijan}} (Observed DST in 1981–1989, 1990–1992 and 1996–2015) # {{flag|Bahrain}} # {{flag|Bangladesh}} (Observed DST in 1942–1945 and 2009-10) # {{flag|Brunei}} # {{flag|Cambodia}} # {{flag|China}} (Observed DST in 1986–1992) # {{flag|East Timor}} # {{flag|Egypt}} (Observed DST in 1940–1945, 1957–2010 and 2014) # {{flag|India}} (Observed DST in 1942–1945 during World War 2) # {{flag|Indonesia}} (Jakarta observed DST in 1948–1950) # {{flag|Iraq}} (Observed DST in 1982–2007) # {{flag|Japan}} (Observed DST in 1948–1951) # {{flag|Kazakhstan}} (Observed DST in 1981–1990 and 1992–2004) # {{flag|Kuwait}} # {{flag|Kyrgyzstan}} (Observed DST in 1981–2005) # {{flag|Laos}} # {{flag|Malaysia}} (Observed DST in 1933–1981) # {{flag|Maldives}} # {{flag|Mongolia}} (Observed DST in 1983–1989; 1990–1998; 2001–2006 and 2015–2017) # {{flag|Myanmar}} # {{flag|Nepal}} # {{flag|North Korea}} # {{flag|Oman}} # {{flag|Pakistan}} (Observed DST in 1942–1945, 2002 and 2008–2009) # {{flag|Philippines}} (Observed DST in 1936–1937, 1954, 1978 and 1990) # {{flag|Qatar}} # {{flag|Russia}} (Observed DST in 1917–1919 and 1921 (some areas), 1981–2010. 2011–2014, used year-round DST. In 2014, Russia discontinued year-round DST and switched back to standard time) # {{flag|Saudi Arabia}} # {{flag|Singapore}} (Observed DST in 1933–1935 by adding 20 minutes to standard time. On January 1, 1936, country changed their time zone to [[UTC+07:20]] which was used till midnight of September 1st, 1941 when it was standardized to [[UTC+07:30]]) # {{flag|South Korea}} (Observed DST in 1948–1951, 1955–1960 and 1987–1988) # {{flag|Sri Lanka}} # {{flag|Taiwan}} (Observed DST in 1945–1962, 1974, 1975 and 1979) # {{flag|Tajikistan}} (Observed DST in 1981–1991) # {{flag|Thailand}} # {{flag|Turkey}} (observed DST from 1985–2016) # {{flag|Turkmenistan}} (Observed DST in 1981–1991) # {{flag|United Arab Emirates}} # {{flag|Uzbekistan}} (Observed DST in 1981–1991) # {{flag|Vietnam}} # {{flag|Yemen}}
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.comment: /* Desert Land in Egypt */ trim def
revision.text:
The '''Egyptian Desert Land Law''' is an [[Egypt]]ian Law No. 143 of 1981 (and its amendments 55/1988, 205/1991, & 96/1995) that governs the acquisition and ownership of desert land in Egypt.
== Desert Land in Egypt == Egypt is predominantly [[desert]]. Only 35,000 km<sup>2</sup> - 3.5% - of the total land area is [[Agriculture|cultivate]]d and permanently settled. Most of the country lies within the wide band of desert that stretches eastwards from Africa's [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic Coast]] across the [[continent]] and into southwest Asia.
Egypt's main desert areas are: * [[Western Desert (Egypt)|Western Desert]] (from the Nile valley to the border with [[Libya]] * [[Eastern Desert]] (from the Nile Valley to the [[Red Sea]] coast) * [[Sinai Peninsula]]
== Principles of the Desert Land Law == Article 1 of Law No. 143 defines desert land as the land two kilometers outside the border of the city. Certain limits are placed on the number of [[feddan]]s (one feddan is equal to 1.038 [[acre]]s or 4200 m²) that may be owned by individuals, families, co-operatives, partnerships and corporations: * up to 150 feddans for individuals. * up to 10,000 feddans for partnerships. * up to 50,000 feddans for joint-stock companies.
Foreign partners and shareholders may be involved, provided Egyptians own at least 51% of the capital. However, upon liquidation of the company, the land must revert to Egyptians. The lease of desert land for more than a period of 50 years shall also be considered to be ownership under Law 143.
Although companies formed under the Investment Law No. 8/1997 do not require Egyptian participation, companies that undertake projects over desert land must be owned in their majority by Egyptians. According to the law 55 of 1988, the President of the Republic may decide to treat Arab nationals as Egyptian nationals for purposes of this law.
== Amendments == 55/1988, 205/1991, & 96/1995
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://taglaw.com/files/Doing%20Business%20Guides/Doing%20Business%20in%20Egypt.pdf Doing Business in Egypt]
[[Category:Egyptian law]] [[Category:Politics of Egypt]]
{{Statute-stub}} {{Egypt-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Expand Dutch|date=March 2016}} {{refimprove|date=January 2013}} [[File:Rijksdaalders met randschrift.jpg|thumb|"God zij met ons" on [[rijksdaalder]]s]] [[File:Edge nederland s01.jpg|thumb|"God zij met ons"]] '''''God zij met ons''''' ({{lang-en|God be with us}}) is a proverb phrase written on [[Kingdom of the Netherlands|Dutch]] [[coin]]s. This caption was formerly written on the edge of the [[Dutch guilder|guilder]], [[rijksdaalder]] (two and a half guilder), five guilders, ten guilders and twenty-five guilders and today on [[Dutch euro coins|2-euro Dutch coins]].<ref>[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:C:2004:051E:0238:0238:EN:PDF Written question P-2322/03 by Véronique De Keyser (PSE) to the Council], ''[[Official Journal of the European Union]]'', 2004. Retrieved 26 September 2012.</ref>
This shortened text expands into its Latin origin "Si Deus nobiscum quis contra nos" (If God is with us, who shall be against us?). This biblical motto was used in the [[Eighty Years' War]] and taken over by the [[Dutch Republic]] for use on its coins.
== See also == * [[In God We Trust]] * [[So help me God]] * [[Gott mit uns]] * [[Dutch Royal Family]] * [[Religion in the Netherlands]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox ethnic group | group = Kokang people | native_name = {{nobold|果敢族
{{my|ကိုးကန့်လူမျိုး}}}} | native_name_lang = zh | image = | image_caption = | total = | total_year = | total_source = | total_ref = | regions = [[Shan State]], [[Myanmar]] | languages = [[Southwestern Mandarin]], [[Burmese language|Burmese]], [[Putonghua]] | religions = | related_groups = [[Burmese Chinese]], [[Han Chinese]], [[Chin Haw]], Other [[Sino-Tibetan peoples]] | footnotes = }} [[File:Kokang.svg|thumb|Map of the Kokang area (in green)]] The '''Kokang people''' ({{zh|c=果敢族|p=Guǒgǎn Zú}}; {{lang-my|ကိုးကန့်လူမျိုး}}) are an [[ethnic group]] of [[Myanmar]]. They are [[Mandarin Chinese|Mandarin]]-speaking [[Han Chinese]]Burma has other, non-Kokang populations of Han Chinese; depending on what area of China they originally immigrated from, these populations speak [[Yunnan#Languages|Yunnanese]], [[Hokkien language|Hokkien]], [[Cantonese language|Cantonese]], [[Hakka language|Hakka]], and [[Hainanese]]. See {{cite book | chapter=The Ethnic Chinese in Myanmar and their Identity | author=Mya Than | title=Ethnic Chinese as Southeast Asians | year=1997 | editor=Leo Suryadinata | publisher=Institute of Southeast Asian Studies | location=Singapore | isbn=981-3055-58-8 | pages=117–8}} living in [[Kokang]], administered as [[Kokang Special Region]] (now [[Kokang Self-Administered Zone]]).{{cite web | url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/sns-ap-as-china-myanmar,0,2397711.story | work=[[Chicago Tribune]] | author=Ng Han Guan | title=Ethnic rebels flee Myanmar, abandoning weapons and uniforms for safe haven in south China | accessdate=30 August 2009}} ==Distribution== In 1997, it was estimated that the Kokang people, together with more recently immigrated [[Yunnan]]ese, constituted 30 to 40 percent of Myanmar's ethnic Chinese population.{{cite book | chapter=The Ethnic Chinese in Myanmar and their Identity | author=Mya Than | title=Ethnic Chinese as Southeast Asians | year=1997 | editor=Leo Suryadinata | publisher=Institute of Southeast Asian Studies | location=Singapore | isbn=981-3055-58-8 | pages=119–20}} ==History== Most Kokang are descendants of Chinese speakers who migrated to what is now [[Shan State]] in the 18th century. In the mid-17th century, the [[Yang (surname)|Yang clan]], a Chinese military house that fled with the [[Ming Dynasty|Ming loyalists]] from [[Nanjing]] to [[Yunnan Province]], and later migrated to the Shan State in eastern Myanmar, formed a feudal state called [[Kokang]]. From the 1960s to 1989, the area was ruled by the [[Communist Party of Burma]], and after the dissolution of that party in 1989 it became a special region of Myanmar. The [[Myanmar National Democratic Alliance Army]] (MNDAA) is a Kokang insurgent group. In August 2009 they clashed with [[Tatmadaw]] soldiers in a conflict fanned by controversial interests known as the [[2009 Kokang incident]].[http://www.internationalrivers.org/blogs/227/chinese-dam-builders-fan-conflict-in-burma Chinese Dam Builders Fan Conflict in Burma] == Notable Kokang == * [[Lo Hsing Han]] * [[Olive Yang]] * [[Sao Edward Yang Kyein Tsai]] == See also == * [[Burmese Chinese]] * [[Kokang Self-Administered Zone]] == References == {{Reflist|2}} {{Ethnic groups in Myanmar}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kokang People}} [[Category:Kokang]] {{Asia-ethno-group-stub}}

{{Distinguish|Operation Overlord}} {{infobox military conflict |conflict = Operation ''Overload |partof = the [[Rhodesian Bush War]] (or Second ''[[Chimurenga]]'') |image = |caption = |date = 27 July 1974 |place= Rhodesia |coordinates= |result = Rhodesian victory * Successful relocation of 60,000 civilians into areas safe from terrorist attacks. |status = |combatant1 ={{flag|Rhodesia}} |combatant2 ={{flagicon image|Flag of ZANU-PF.svg}} [[Zimbabwe African National Liberation Army|ZANLA]] |commander1 ={{flagicon|Rhodesia}} [[Ian Smith]] |commander2 ={{flagicon image|Flag of ZANU-PF.svg}} Unknown |units1 ={{flagicon image|Rhodesian Army flag late 1970s.png|23px}} [[Rhodesian Army]] |units2 =unknown |strength1 =4,700 regulars
8,000 police
10,000 territorials
60,000 reservists |strength2 =unknown |casualties1 =37 killed |casualties2 =300 killed |casualties3 ='''Civilian Casualties''':
11 Europeans killed
74 Africans killed
850 Africans kidnapped }} {{Campaignbox Rhodesian Bush War}} '''Operation Overload''' was a military operation by the [[Rhodesian Army]] that took place over six weeks starting on 27 July 1974. The operation resulted in the movement of 49,960 people into twenty-one [[Villagization|protected villages]] in the [[Chiweshe Tribal Trust Land]]. The people were moved into the protected villages to prevent them from being attacked or killed by the insurgents. Unfortunately the relocation resulted in the deaths of a few of the people being moved most likely due to attempts by the insurgents to prevent the relocation.{{cite book|last1=Cilliers|first1=Jakkie|title=Counter-Insurgency in Rhodesia|date=2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=1317499247|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=VHRKCAAAQBAJ&dq=Counter-Insurgency+in+Rhodesia&source=gbs_navlinks_s}} But despite this unintended and regrettable tragedy the operation was a success due to professionalism of the [[Rhodesian Security Forces]].{{Harvnb |Geldenhuys |Preller |2007 |pp=96}} People in the northern Chiweshe area had been subject to violent political intimidation by [[ZANLA]], and so for the most part moved willingly, but in the southern part of the area, where support for the cadres was a little stronger, a small amount resistance was encountered. The security forces destroyed the old huts after their occupants had moved. "In the short term, benefits seemed substantial," says Cilliers, "as insurgent activities were severely disrupted in [[Chiweshe]] for the following six months." The security forces immediately set about a similar operation called ''Overload Two'' in the Madziwa Tribal Trust Lands, which met with further success. ==Aftermath== Although initially successful, the protected villages ultimately proved counter-productive for the security forces. Cilliers cites the "lack of emphasis on concurrent socio-economic conditions" as a negative factor, pointing out the lack of sanitation and other facilities in most of the villages, as well as the fact that they were not sufficiently guarded. Wood agrees, saying that the villages "were never adequately policed or protected and the people were not involved in their management or persuaded of their necessity." Because of the inadequate financial backing for the PVs they were not developed properly, and their locations were often too far from the fields where the villagers grew their crops. The village administration was poor to the extent that in numerous cases ZANLA insurgents were able to use them as hiding places. "Most important of all," Wood concludes, the protected villages "took the people away from the burial sites of their ancestors, which they venerated." The PVs lasted until 1978, when they were dismantled. This combined with the effectiveness of the recently formed Selous Scouts to reduce ZANLA influence in the area and force the cadres back to the north, towards Mozambique. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{reflist|group=n}} ===Bibliography=== *{{Cite book |title=Rhodesian Air Force Operations with Air Strike Log |last1=Geldenhuys |first1=Preller |authorlink1=Preller Geldenhuys |publisher=Just Done Productions Publishing |year=2007 |isbn=978-1-920169-61-9 |location=Durban, South Africa |pages= |url=http://www.justdone.co.za/shop/index.php?id_product=29&controller=product |publication-date=13 July 2007|ref=harv}} {{coord missing|Zimbabwe}} [[Category:1974 in Rhodesia]] [[Category:Battles and operations of the Rhodesian Bush War]] [[Category:Forced migration]] [[Category:1974 in military history]] {{africa-mil-stub}} {{Rhodesia-stub}}

{{Infobox film | name = Parallel Voices | image = Parallel Voices poster.jpg | director = [[Rustam Khamdamov]] | producer = Aleksandr Vaynshteyn | story = | writer = Rustam Khamdamov
[[Renata Litvinova]] | starring = Renata Litvinova | cinematography = Rifkat Ibragimov
Sergey Mokritsky | music = [[Vladimir Martynov]] | editing = | distributor = | country = Kazakhstan | language = Russian | released = {{Film date|2005}} }} '''''Parallel Voices''''' ({{lang-ru|Вокальные параллели}}, "''Vokaldy paralelder''") is a 2005 Kazakhstani musical drama film written and directed by [[Rustam Khamdamov]]. It was the first film directed by Khamdamov after a 14 years hiatus. It was entered into the Horizons section at the [[62nd Venice International Film Festival|62nd edition]] of the [[Venice Film Festival]].{{cite news|last1= Leslie Felperin |title=Review: ‘Parallel Voices’|url=https://variety.com/2005/film/reviews/parallel-voices-1200524802/|accessdate=2 June 2016|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=June 30, 2005}}{{cite news|last1=Polina Barskova|title=Amidst Ruins: Rustam Khamdamov’s Vocal Parallels |url=http://www.kinokultura.com/2006/11r-vocalpara.shtml|accessdate=2 June 2016|work=KinoKultura|date=February 16, 2006}}{{cite news|last1=Eugene Hernandez|title=With A Record Eleven U.S. Titles, Venice Fest Sets 2005 Lineup|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2005/07/with-a-record-eleven-u-s-titles-venice-fest-sets-2005-lineup-78106/|accessdate=June 1, 2016|work=[[IndieWire]]|date=July 29, 2005}} == Plot == {{expand section|date=June 2016}} A group of Russian artists met in a desolate hangar, where they will alternate classical [[aria]]s and discussions about the sense of life. == Cast == * [[Renata Litvinova]] as Herself * {{Interlanguage link multi|Roza Dzhamanova|ru|3=Джаманова, Роза Умбетовна}} as Herself * {{Interlanguage link multi|Bibigul Tulegenova|ru|3=Вокальные параллели}} as Herself * [[Erik Kurmangaliev]] as Himself * {{Interlanguage link multi|Araks Davtyan|ru|3=Давтян, Араксия Ашотовна}} as Herself == References == == External links == *{{IMDb title}} [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:2000s musical films]] [[Category:Kazakhstani films]] [[Category:Musical drama films]] {{musical-drama-film-stub}} {{Kazakhstan-film-stub}}

{{one source|date=February 2016}}{{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Portugal}} "Penso em ti, eu sei" | image = | caption = | year = 1985 | country = Portugal | artist = Adelaide Ferreira | as = Adelaide | with = | language = Portuguese | languages = | composer = Tozé Brito | lyricist = Adelaide, Luís Fernando | conductor = José Calvario | place = 18th | points = 9 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1985pt from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Silêncio e tanta gente | prev_link = Silêncio e tanta gente | next = Não sejas mau para mim | next_link = Não sejas mau para mim }} '''"Penso em ti, eu sei"''' ("I Think of you, I know") was the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1985]], performed in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] by [[Adelaide Ferreira|Adelaide]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Letra da canção e outras informações sobre a canção|url=http://www.diggiloo.net/?1985pt|publisher=www.diggiloo.net|accessdate=15 February 2016}}</ref>
The song is a ballad, with Adelaide telling her lover how she feels as their relationship comes to an end. The lyrics suggest that she will in fact end the relationship the moment the song ends, thus producing the conflicted emotions she feels.
The song was performed ninth on the night, following [[Belgium]]'s [[Linda Lepomme]] with "[[Laat me nu gaan]]" and preceding [[Germany]]'s [[Wind (band)|Wind]] with "[[Für alle]]". At the close of voting, it had received 9 points, placing 18th in a field of 19.
It was succeeded as [[Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest|Portuguese representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1986|1986 Contest]] by [[Dora (singer)|Dora]] with "[[Não sejas mau para mim]]".
==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Portugal]] [[Category:Portuguese-language songs]]

revision.text:
{{For|the South Korean Presidential Security Service|Presidential Security Service}} {{Infobox Law enforcement agency |agencyname = Presidential Security Service of Belarus |nativename = Служба бяспекі прэзiдэнта Республікi Беларусь |nativenamea = |nativenamer = |commonname = Presidential Security Service |abbreviation = SBP |patch = |patchcaption = |logo = |logocaption = |badge = |badgecaption = |flag = |flagcaption = |motto = |mottotranslated = |formedyear = 1991 |formedmonthday = |preceding1 = [[Ninth Chief Directorate]] (KGB) |employees = |volunteers = |budget = |nongovernment = |country = Belarus |countryabbr = |federal = |map = |mapcaption = |sizearea = |sizepopulation = |legaljuris = |governingbody = Presidential Administration of Belarus |governingbodyscnd = |constitution1 = |speciality = |overviewtype = |overviewbody = |headquarters = [[Minsk]] |hqlocmap = |hqlocleft = |hqloctop = |hqlocmappoptitle = |sworntype = |sworn = |unsworntype = |unsworn = |electeetype = |minister1name = |minister1pfo = |chief1name = Major General [[Viktor Shinkevich]] |chief1position = Commander |parentagency = |child1agency = |unittype = |unitname = |officetype = |officename = |provideragency = |uniformedas = |stationtype = |stations = |airbases = |lockuptype = |lockups = |vehicle1type = |vehicles1 = |boat1type = |boats1 = |aircraft1type = |aircraft1 = |animal1type = |animals1 = |person1name = |person1reason = |person1type = |programme1 = |activity1name = |activitytype = |anniversary1 = |award1 = |website = |footnotes = |reference = }}
The [[Belarus]]ian '''Presidential Guard''' or officially the '''Presidential Security Service''' ({{lang-ru|Служба безопасности Президента Республики Беларусь}}, {{lang-be|Служба бяспекі прэзiдэнта Республікi Беларусь}}) is a law-enforcement body that was designed to protect the [[President of Belarus]] and other high-ranking officials and officers.
==Role in political repressions==
According to the US and the European Union, the Presidential Security Service and its commanders are actively involved in [[Human rights in Belarus|human rights violations and political repressions]] in Belarus.
===Role during the referendum of 1996===
According to the Belarusian opposition, the Presidential Security Service has played a key role in the events around the [[Belarusian referendum, 1996|controversial referendum of 1996]], which has resulted in the dissolution of the disloyal [[Supreme Soviet of Belarus]] and an ultimate concentration of state power in the hands of authoritarian president [[Alexander Lukashenko]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://govorim.by/novosti-belarusi/29040-andrey-klimov-esli-by-ne-predatelstvo-rukovodstva-verhovnogo-soveta-lukashenko-ne-udalos-by-sovershit-perevorot.html|title=Андрей Климов: Если бы не предательство руководства Верховного Совета, Лукашенко не удалось бы совершить переворот|trans-title=Andrey Klimau:"If there wouldn't be a treason by the Supreme Soviet, Lukashenko would not have managed to organize his coup d'etat"|date=24 November 2011|accessdate=16 November 2017}}</ref><ref name=hancar>{{cite web|url=https://www.nv-online.info/np/viktor-gonchar-ya-gord-tem-chto-mne-udalos-sdelat/|title=Виктор ГОНЧАР: «Я горд тем, что мне удалось сделать…»|trans-title=Viktar Hanchar:"I'm proud of what I've managed to do..."|date=25 November 2016|accessdate=16 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.belaruspartisan.org/politic/106262/|title=Десять лет назад сотрудники Службы безопасности президента захватили Центризбирком|trans-title=Ten years ago, soldiers of the Presidential Security Service took over the Central Elections Commission|date=20 November 2006|publisher=[[Belorussky Partizan]]|language=Russian|accessdate=16 November 2017}}</ref>
Before the controversial referendum, the Presidential Security Service has blocked the office of the [[Central Election Commission of Belarus]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.tut.by/society/520859.html|title=Интервью с Лидией Ермошиной: Пока ты в системе — ты должен быть лоялен к власти|trans-title=Interview with Lidiya Yermoshina: "As long as you are in the System, you have to be loyal to the authorities"|last=Ванкович|first=Александр|date=22 November 2016|publisher=[[TUT.by]]|language=Russian|accessdate=16 November 2017}}</ref> and prevented the Head of the Commission, [[Viktar Hanchar]] from executing his role.<ref name=hancar/> [[Lidia Yermoshina]], a member of the Commission loyal to Lukashenko, has been appointed instead of Hanchar. Three years later, Viktar Hanchar has disappeared and was presumably murdered.
After the events, the [[United States]] [[United States Department of State|State Department]] stated that the Presidential Guard is a [[secret police]] force under the control of [[President of Belarus|President]] [[Alexander Lukashenko]]. The State Department in 1996 stated the guard was allowed to use force "''against the President's political enemies with no judicial or legislative oversight."''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/1999/319.htm|title=Country Reports on Human Rights Practices Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor 1999|date=February 23, 2000|publisher=[[United States Department of State]]|accessdate=16 November 2017}}</ref>
===Sanctions against officers of the Presidential Guard===
Several former Heads of the Presidential Security Service have been included in the sanctions lists of the [[European Union]] and the [[United States]]:<ref>[https://nn.by/?c=ar&i=61552 Поўны спіс 208 беларускіх чыноўнікаў, якім забаронены ўезд у ЕС] - [[Nasha Niva]], 11.10.2011</ref>
* [[Uladzimir Navumau|Vladimir Naumov]] as former [[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Belarus)|Minister of Interior]] has allegedly failed to investigate the unresolved disappearances of opposition leaders [[Yuri Zakharenko]] and [[Viktar Hanchar]], opposition sponsor Anatoly Krasovski, and journalist [[Dmitri Zavadski]] in 1999-2000. He has been included in the [[List of people and organizations sanctioned in relation to human rights violations in Belarus|sanctions list of the European Union in 2011]] and is one of four persons remaining under EU sanctions after 2016. He is also on the sanctions list of the [[United States]]. Besides that, as one of the persons accused of involvement in the disappearances of 1999-2000, Naumov remains one of the few people on the sanctions list of the [[United States]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sanctionssearch.ofac.treas.gov/Details.aspx?id=1498|title=OFAC Sanctions List Search|accessdate=7 November 2017}}</ref>
* [[Gennady Nevyglas]], according to the [[Council of the European Union|EU Council]]'s decision following the 2010 wave of repressions,<ref name=EU2012>[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/dec/2012/642/oj Council Decision 2012/642/CFSP of 15 October 2012 concerning restrictive measures against Belarus]</ref> was "''responsible for organising [[Belarusian presidential election, 2006|fraudulent [presidential] elections in 2006]] and in the subsequent repression of peaceful demonstrators''". He has been included in the [[List of people and organizations sanctioned in relation to human rights violations in Belarus|sanctions list of the European Union in 2011]].
* [[Yuri Zhadobin]] has been described in the [[European Council|EU Council]]'s 2012 decision on sanctions as follows: ''"As a member of the Security Council, he approves the repressive decisions agreed at ministerial level, including the decision to repress the peaceful demonstrations on 19 December 2010. After December 2010, he praised the "total defeat of destructive forces", when referring to the democratic opposition."'' <ref name=EU2012/> He has been included in the [[List of people and organizations sanctioned in relation to human rights violations in Belarus|sanctions list of the European Union in 2011]].
* [[Andrei Vtiurin]] has allegedly supervised interrogations of arrested protesters after the demonstrations that followed 2010 presidential elections. He has been included in the [[List of people and organizations sanctioned in relation to human rights violations in Belarus|sanctions list of the European Union in 2011]].<ref name=EU2012/>
== Commanders == * [[Vycheslav Korolev]] (November 1994 - 1995) * [[Yuri Borodich]] (1995 - December 2, 1998) * [[Vladimir Kuzhanov]] (Acting) (December 2, 1998 - January 20, 1999) * [[Uladzimir Navumau|Vladimir Naumov]] (January 20, 1999 - September 25, 2000) * [[Leonid Erin]] (September 25 - November 27, 2000) * [[Gennady Nevyglas]] (December 4, 2000 - September 12, 2001) * Vladimir Klimov (Acting) (September 19, 2001 - October 5, 2001) * [[Evgeny Dvernitsky]] (October 5, 2001 - September 10, 2003) * [[Yuri Zhadobin]] (September 10, 2003 - July 17, 2007) * [[Andrey Vtiurin]] (July 17, 2007 - September 11, 2014) * [[Viktor Shinkevich]] (October 20, 2014 - Present)
== External links == * [http://www.usemb.se/human/human96/belarus.html U.S. Embassy infopage]
==References== <references/>

{{legend|#0000ff|Diocese of Kotor}}{{legend|#9dffce|Archdiocese of Bar}} | website = | footnotes = }} The '''Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bar''' ([[Montenegrin language|Montenegrin]] and [[Serbian language|Serbian]]: ''Barska nadbiskupija'' / Барска надбискупија, {{lang-sq|Kryedioqeza e Tivarit}}, {{lang-la|Archidioecesis Antibarensis}}) is an ecclesiastical territory or [[diocese]] of the [[Roman Catholic Church]] in [[Montenegro]].[http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dbary.html "Archdiocese of Bar (Antivari)"] ''[[Catholic-Hierarchy.org]]''. David M. Cheney. Retrieved February 29, 2016[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/barz0.htm "Archdiocese of Bar"] ''GCatholic.org''. Gabriel Chow. Retrieved February 29, 2016 It is centred in the city of [[Bar, Montenegro|Bar]] (Italian ''Antivari''). It was erected as a diocese in the 9th century and elevated to an archdiocese in 1089. The Archbishopric was by Pope's decree abolished some time after 1140, until it was restored by the Serbian medieval [[Nemanjić]] dynasty in 1199. The Archbishops regularly bore titles of "[[Primate (bishop)|Primates]] of Serbia" (''Primas Serviae''), implemented as a permanent part of the title by Archbishop [[Stephen Tegliatti]] in 1475, since 1256 early on self-styled as "Archbishop of Slavians".Serbs, referring to the Serbian medieval state The archdiocese's new cathedral is the [[Cathedral of Saint Peter the Apostle (Bar)|Cathedral of Saint Peter the Apostle]] (consecrated in September 2017) in Bar.{{cite web|url=http://www.vijesti.me/vijesti/osvestana-barska-katedrala-svetog-petra-952793|title=Osveštana barska katedrala Svetog Petra|accessdate=1 July 2018|date=3 September 2017|language=Serbian}} Its old [[Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception (Bar)|Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception]] is located near [[Stari Bar]]. [[Rrok Gjonlleshaj]] currently serves as archbishop in the archdiocese.International Bishops' Conference of St. Cyril and Methodius: [http://www.ceicem.org/bar.html ''Diocese of Bar''] In 1923, [[Traboin]], [[Tuzi]], [[Grude]], and [[Klezna]] were added to the Archbishopric from the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Shkodër-Pult|Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Shkodër]]. In 1969, the territory of the municipalities of [[Plav, Montenegro|Plav]], [[Gusinje]], and [[Vojno Selo]] were added to the Archbishopric from the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Skopje]]. ==Archbishops== *Peter (1064–1094) *Sergius (1094?/ca. 1110?–1124?) *Elijah (ca. 1124 – 1140) *John I (1199–1247) *John II ([[Giovanni da Pian del Carpine]]) (1248–1252) *Gufrid (April 1253 – 1254) *Lawrence I (1255–1270) *Gašpar Adam (1270–1280) *Michael (1282–1298) *Rudger (1298–1301), member of the

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} The '''Vested Property Act''' is a controversial law in [[Bangladesh]] that allows the Government to confiscate property from individuals it deems as an ''enemy of the state''. Before the independence of Bangladesh in 1971, it was known as the Enemy Property Act and is still referred to as such in common parlance. The act is criticized as a tool for appropriating the lands of the minority population.
==Background== {{Persecution of Bengali Hindus}}
===Legal history===
This law is the culmination of several successive discriminatory laws against non-Muslims passed while Bangladesh was part of Pakistan.
Chronologically, they are: * The East Bengal (Emergency) Requisition of Property Act (XIII of 1948) * The East Bengal Evacuees (Administration of Property) Act (VIII of 1949) * The East Bengal Evacuees (Restoration of Possession) Act (XXII of 1951) * The East Bengal Evacuees (Administration of Immovable Property) Act (XXIV of 1951) * The East Bengal Prevention of Transfer of Property and Removal of Documents and Records Act of 1952 * The Pakistan (Administration of Evacuees Property) Act (XII of 1957) * The East Pakistan Disturbed Persons (Rehabilitation) Ordinance (No 1 of 1964) * The Defence of Pakistan Ordinance (No. XXIII of 6 September 1965) * The Defence of Pakistan Rules of 1965 * The Enemy Property (Custody and Registration) Order of 1965 * The East Pakistan Enemy Property (Lands and Buildings Administration and Disposal Order of 1966). * The Enemy Property (Continuance of Emergency Provision) Ordinance No. 1 of 1969 * Bangladesh (Vesting of Property and Assets) President's (Order No. 29 of 1972). * The Enemy Property (Continuance of Emergency Provisions) (Repeal) Act (XLV of 1974) * The Vested and Non-Resident Property (Administration) Act (XLVI of 1974) * The vested and Non-Resident (Administration) (Repeal) Ordinance 1976 The Ordinance, (No. XCII of 1976). * The Ordinance No. XCIII of 1976.
On 6 November 2008, the High Court division of the Supreme Court of Bangladesh delivered its [[rule nisi]] upon the Government on the Enemy Property (Continuance of Emergency Provision) (Repeal) Act 1974 and subsequently promulgated Arpita Sampatty Protapyan Ain 2001 and circulars, administrative orders.
The order calls upon the respondent to show cause as to why instructions issued in the contents of presidential order 29 of 1972, act 45 and 46 of 1974, ordinance No. 92, 93 of 1976, Arpita Sampatty Protapyan Ain 2001 and circulars issued by government that are in contradiction with the fundamental rights and the charter of declaration of Independence of Bangladesh, 10 April 1971, should not be declared to be [[ultra vires]] the constitution.The Rule Nisi also stated why the properties so far incorporated in the list as Enemy (Vested) should not be returned to the title holder/successor/legal possession holders and or such other or further order or orders passed as to this Court may seem fit and proper. The Rule is made returnable within 4 weeks from 28 October 2008. {{Citation needed|date=November 2008}}
===Renamed as Vested Property Act===
Though renamed as the Vested Property Act in 1974, the law still retains the fundamental ability to deprive a Bangladeshi citizen of his/her property simply by declaration of that person as an enemy of the state. Leaving the country through abandonment is cited as the most common reason for this, and it is frequently the case {{Citation needed|date=November 2008}} that Hindu families who have one or several members leaving the country (due to religious atrocities against Hindus, and economic as well as political reasons) have their entire property confiscated due to labeling as enemy.<ref name=refworldunhc>{{cite web |url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/country,,MRGI,,BGD,,49749d572d,0.html |title=World Directory of Minorities and Indigenous Peoples - Bangladesh : Hindus |date=2 May 2012 |website=UNHCR |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018084914/http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/country,,MRGI,,BGD,,49749d572d,0.html |archive-date=18 October 2012}}</ref>
==Measurable impact==
===Newspaper reports===
The Bangladeshi newspaper ''[[The Sangbad]]'' (21 March 1977) reported that at that point in time, according to the government's own figures, 702,335 acres (2,842 km²) of cultivable land and 22,835 homes were listed as enemy property. {{More citations needed|date=November 2008}}
===Prominent cases===
Much of the property of murdered Hindu politician [[Dhirendranath Datta]] was confiscated by the Bangladesh government after independence in 1971 {{Citation needed|date=November 2008}}. Because Datta's body was never found after he was arrested by the [[Pakistan Army]] during the [[Bangladesh Liberation War]], an affidavit was brought forward that it could not be concluded that Datta had not voluntarily left the country.
The family property of Nobel Prize–winning economist [[Amartya Sen]] had been confiscated by the Pakistan government. In 1999, the Bangladesh government announced that it was investigating opportunities to return the property to Sen's family.<ref>{{citation |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/law/2007/04/03/rights.htm |title=Vested Property Act: A story of deprivation and exploitation |author=Dipanwita Roy |date=21 April 2007 |accessdate=28 November 2015}}</ref>
===Barkat's seminal work===
A seminal book by Professor Abul Barkat of [[Dhaka University]], ''Inquiry into Causes and Consequences of Deprivation of Hindu Minorities in Bangladesh through the Vested Property Act'', was published in 2000.{{Citation needed|date=November 2008}} It demonstrated that 925,050 Hindu households (40% of Hindu families in Bangladesh) have been affected by the Enemy Property Act. This included 748,850 families dispossessed of agricultural land. The total amount of land lost by Hindu households as a result of this discriminatory act was estimated at 1.64 million acres (6,640 km²), which is equivalent to 53 per cent of the total land owned by the Hindu community and 5.3 per cent of the total land area of Bangladesh.
The survey also showed that the beneficiaries of the land grab through the act cut across all party lines. The political affiliation of direct beneficiaries of appropriated property was: * [[Bangladesh Awami League]] 44.2% * [[Bangladesh Nationalist Party]] (BNP) 31.7% * [[Jatiya Party (Ershad)|Jatiya Party]] 5.8% * [[Bangladesh Jamaat-e-Islami|Jamaat-e-Islami]] 4.8% * Others 13.5%
The greatest appropriation of Hindu property took place immediately after independence during the first Awami League government (1972–75) and during the first period of rule of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (1976-1980). Barkat's work also showed that since 1948, 75% of the land of religious minorities in East Pakistan and subsequent Bangladesh had been confiscated through provisions of the act.
Barkat also emphasized that less than 0.4% of the population of Bangladesh has benefited from the Enemy Property Act, demonstrating that this law has been abused by those in power through corruption, with no demonstrated sanction by the population at large.
===Effect on Bangladeshi demographics===
The law in its implementation has been seen as a major driver behind the reduction of the [[Hinduism in Bangladesh|Bangladeshi Hindu]] population, which has declined from an estimated 30% in 1947,<ref>http://hinduism.about.com/od/history/a/humanrights.htm</ref> to 17% in 1965 to 16% today,<ref>{{cite web|title=Background Note: Bangladesh|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/3452.htm|publisher=Bureau of South and Central Asian Affairs, U.S. Department of State|accessdate=1 September 2012}}</ref> representing a loss of around 11 million people. Most of this population left for India, while the more affluent Bangladeshi Hindus leaving due to the act have moved to USA, Canada, Europe and Australia.
==Repeal of the act==
During Bangladesh's first three decades of independence many politicians made empty promised to repeal the act. The first government of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman vowed to repeal any laws that contradicted the values of the newly liberated country; the Enemy Property Act contravened non-communal provisions of the new constitution. But instead of being repealed it was sustained under a new name in 1974.
Finally in the run up to the 2001 election [[Sheikh Hasina]] and the [[Awami League]] succeeded in a drive to repeal the act.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/bangla14864.htm |title=Bangladesh: Essential Background |date=2007 |website=Human Rights Watch |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070224083954/http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/bangla14864.htm |archive-date=24 February 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=The legacy of enemy turned vested property act in Bangladesh |url=http://www.asiantribune.com/index.php?q=node/5925 |newspaper=Asian Tribune |date=29 May 2007}}</ref><ref>[https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2002/14021.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2002: Bangladesh], US Department of State</ref> The Vested Properties Return Act (2001) was implemented (in a session boycotted by the opposition BNP and Jamaat members) in an effort to make amends for the confiscated property. However little progress has been made in returning or compensating lost property under the [[Khaleda Zia]] government from 2001-2006.<ref>{{cite news |title=Hindu properties continue to be 'vested' |url=http://www.newagebd.com/2007/may/26/front.html#1 |newspaper=New Age |location=Dhaka |date=26 May 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930203518/http://www.newagebd.com/2007/may/26/front.html#1 |archive-date=30 September 2007}}</ref> In 2008, [HRCBM (Human Rights Congress for Bangladesh Minorities)] [http://www.hrcbm.org/] filed a writ before [[Bangladesh Supreme Court]] under article 102 of the constitution.<ref>[http://quandaryreflection.blogspot.com/2008/08/hrcbms-litigation-against-government-of.html WRIT PETITION NO. 6092 OF 2008], HRCBM (2008)</ref>
==International concern==
Congressman Crowley of the Bangladesh-American caucus has called for the repeal of the act {{Citation needed|date=November 2008}}, as have several Bangladeshi politicians and human rights activists. The current opposition Awami League has vowed to repeal the act if returned to power in the next elections, even though it has yet to acknowledge its own participation in implementation of the act during the 1972-75 period.
An international conference organized by several Hindu activist groups held in London on 16 June 2005 was addressed by, among others, Lord Avebury of the British House of Lords and called for repeal of the act. {{Citation needed|date=November 2008}}
The law has been highlighted by the [[U.S. Department of State]] and [[Amnesty International]] as a major human rights concern that has contributed to internal displacement, emigration and disenfranchisement. {{Citation needed|date=November 2008}}
==References== <references />
==Further reading== * Abul Barkat, Azizur Rahman, Shafique uz Zaman, Avijit Poddar: Impact of vested property act on rural Bangladesh: an exploratory study. Prepared for Association for Land Reform and Development, Bangladesh. Dhaka: University Research Corporation. 1996. * Abul Barkat (ed.): An inquiry into causes and consequences of deprivation of Hindu minorities in Bangladesh through the Vested Property Act: framework for a realistic solution. Dhaka: PRIP Trust. 2000. * ''Deprivation of affected million families: Living with Vested Property in Bangladesh'', Abul Barkat, forthcoming.
